results.title: Gaza Strip
results.brief_description: James Longely’s “Gaza Strip” documents the lives of Palestinians living inside the cramped Israeli territory. Filmed in the context of the second Intifada in September 2000 and prior to the election of far rightwing Likud leader Ariel Sharon, what follows is a narrative loosely based around the 13 year old Mohammed Hejazzi. Mohammed’s education was short lived due to the dependency on him as sole provider for his household. The loss of childhood innocence is captured by powerful scenes of the boy hurling stones at the surrounding Israeli occupied territories following the death of his close friend by Israeli gunfire. Through Mohammed’s eyes are seen the crowding caused by illegal Israeli settlements, the use of neurological gas against civilians, the fallout caused by unexploded artillery, the constant influx of ambulance vehicles and hospital queues. Much of “Gaza Strip” unfolds through gripping and powerful images without the use of lengthy interviews or a political dialogue, but rather startling audiovisual bites of the daily struggle within Gaza. Perhaps the most moving and disturbing moment in “Gaza” is the admission of an infant child contemplating the life of a martyr. “Gaza Strip” is Longley’s first feature. In Arabic with English subtitles.

results.title: Gaudi afternoon
results.creator_credit: Lola Films, Antenna 3 Television, Via Digital, Andres Gomes and Susan Seidelman
results.brief_description: Cassandra Reilly (Judy Davis) is a nomadic American translator living in Barcelona, Spain who takes on a missing person job as she is short of funds. She finds herself working for the mysterious and beautiful Frankie Stevens (Marcia Gay Harden). Frankie however does not tell Reilly the full story and Reilly becomes intrigued by different characters that she starts to trail, including Ben (Lili Taylor), a butch American lesbian, April (Juliette Lewis), her bohemian girlfriend and Hamilton, their friend, a bi-sexual magician. Davis plays Cassandra as a clumsy, self-conscious and straight-laced neurotic who is a fish-out-of-water in the ‘exotic’ gay and lesbian scene. A cross-dressing black comedy, “Gaudi afternoon” is an amusing undertaking from director Susan Seidelman (Desperately seeking Susan, She-devil), who spent ten years directing for television before returning to film with this feature. Seidelman never seems to quite make all the elements gel but the impressive cast and beautiful locale go some way to making the film an enjoyable ride. Fans of “Desperately seeking Susan” may be interested to decipher the similarities between the two narratives here.

results.title: Gattaca [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Jersey Films, Danny DeVito, Michael Shamberg, Stacey Sher and Andrew Niccol
results.brief_description: Niccol’s debut as a director, a year before he wrote the script for ‘The Truman Show’, is set in a near-future where the lives of the majority of citizens are determined before birth through genetic engineering of their genes, and the ‘natural-born’ minority of ‘In-Valids’ is shunned. Vincent Freeman (Ethan Hawke) is one of the latter, who, in order to pursue his goal of travelling into space, assumes the identity of a member of the genetic elite (Jude Law). His cover is threatened when he becomes a suspect in a murder investigation. With a relentless investigator in pursuit and the colleague he has fallen in love with beginning to suspect his deception, his dreams begin to unravel. Cast includes Uma Thurman, Ethan Hawke, Alan Arkin, Jude Law and Ernest Borgnine.

results.title: Gathering threads = Tui Tuia
results.creator_credit: Nga Kara Whetu, TopShelf Productions, Carol J Paewai and Christina Ngahuia Asher
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “From spirit to spirit (A)”.
The art of weaving is an important cultural, social and economic activity among the Maori and Pacific Islander peoples. Aotearoa Moananui and Kiwa weavers are determined to continue the craft. Modern technology has allowed them to cultivate, protect and develop their art as part of their heritage.

results.title: Gathering of the clans
results.brief_description: Scenes at the Gathering of the Clans held at Inverness in 1966. Traditional dancing, sports and the pipe band contest are shown. The history of Scottish culture as represented at the Gathering is briefly discussed.

results.title: Gateway to independence
results.brief_description: A guide dog gives independence to a blind person. Shows the careful selection and training of dogs and the training of the people who will use these dogs as aids to daily living. It stresses that complete confidence in the dog by its owner is essential for the success of the enterprise. Cinematography by Tom Cowan.

results.title: Gateway to charm
results.brief_description: the tourist attractions of the north coast of Tasmania. The towns of Wynyard, Burnie, Stanley, Penguin, Ulverston and Devonport are shown, with their beaches, ocean and fresh-water fishing, sporting and camping facilities, and natural scenic attractions. The beauties of the rocky coast are displayed. Aboriginal rock paintings, fossils and the ruins of pioneer settlements can also be seen.

results.title: Gateway to Asia
results.brief_description: With the distance between Canada and Russia, China and India cut by high-speed planes, new international links are being forged. In this Pacific world, British Columbia is a unit of growing importance. In a brief survey of the province, Gateway to Asia covers the people, natural resources, industries, and some of the social problems of British Columbia. Located on the Pacific Coast, it is the jumping-off place for planes bound for the Orient and Russia, and a vital link between the rest of Canada and her neighbors in the Far East. Narrated by Lorne Greene.
